div.p: >> Hi, this is Joyce Farrell.

Let's
take a quick look

at the logic behind
merging files.

You can merge files when
you have two or more files
that are in the same format.
That means that the records

in both files contain the
same fields, in the same order.
You also can merge files

when the two files are
sorted using the same field.

In other words, if the two
files hold customer records,

both have to be sorted in ID
number order, or both have

to be sorted by last name of
the customer, or maybe both have
to be sorted by zip code.

It doesn't matter which field
they're sorted by, but they have

to be sorted using
the same field.

For example, let's
take a simple file

that just stores the first
name of your friends.

You have 5 friends and
they're in alphabetical order.

Suppose I also have a file of
friends, and my friends are
in alphabetical order.

What you might want to do
is create a merged listed

in which all the names
are in alphabetical order

and the merged file
contains each record
from the first two files.
Here's how the logic would work.

You read in one record
from each of the files.

So, in this case, your
first friend is Beth,
and my first friend is Ann.

You compare the two and
see which one is less.

The one that's less
alphabetically is the one
that comes first alphabetically.

In other words, in
this case it's Ann.

So, you would write
Ann to the output file

and read the next record
in the My friends file.
Then you compare Beth and Don.

Beth is less alphabetically,
so you write Beth

to the output file,
and read another record

from the Your friends
file, which is Carl.
You compare Carl and Don.

Carl is less, so you write
Carl to output and read George.

You compare Don and George,
Don is less, so you write Don

to output file, and read
Emily from My friends file.

When you compare George
and Emily, Emily is less,

so it gets sent to
output and you read Fred.

George and Fred, Fred is less,
so you send Fred to output

and you read past
the end of the file.

You can't quit the program yet
because there are still more

of Your friends to
be sent to output.

So, a trick the programmers use
is to put a very high value

in memory in the spot where
the My friends name would be.

By a high value, we
mean something

that alphabetically
will always fall
after every name in the list.
In this case, ZZZZZ will work.

If we were sorting on a numeric
field, we might use a value
like 99999.

Anyhow, we now compare George
and ZZZ, and George is less,

so George is written to output
and we read Hannah into memory.

Hannah is less than
ZZZ, so Hannah is sent
to output and we read Iris.

Iris is less than ZZZ,
so we send Iris to output

and set Your friends
name to ZZZ.

When both names are the Zs,
that's the end of the program,

and you've produced a
final merged friends list.
Thanks for watching.
